expansion-factorisation-node-1.title: Identifying Quadratic Expressions
learningFocus: Define quadratic expression as ax² + bx + c where a ≠ 0
Identify x² term as defining characteristic
Name coefficients: a (of x²), b (of x), c (constant)

exemplarProblems.problemText: Is the expression 3x² + 5x - 2 a quadratic expression? If yes, identify the values of a, b, and c.
Consider the expression 7x + 4. Is this a quadratic expression? Explain why or why not.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: No. It is linear because there is no x² term (a = 0)

questionTypes: Is this quadratic? Identify a, b, c

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool for definition questions - no visual needed
Use various forms: standard, missing terms, non-quadratic examples
Include both positive and negative coefficients
For missing terms, emphasize b=0 or c=0 (not omitted)
Mix quadratic and non-quadratic examples for discrimination
Always ask for coefficient identification when quadratic
Use unicode for exponents: x² not x^2

expansion-factorisation-node-2.title: Adding and Subtracting Quadratic Expressions
learningFocus: Identify like terms in quadratic expressions
Combine x² terms, x terms, and constants separately
Handle negative coefficients and signs correctly
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - this is algebraic manipulation
Always require full simplification in standard form ax² + bx + c
Include negative coefficients to test sign handling
For subtraction, ensure proper sign changes: -(a) = -a
Test combining like terms across x², x, and constant
Vary difficulty: 2 expressions (easier) to 3+ expressions (harder)
Final answer must be in descending power order: x² then x then constant

expansion-factorisation-node-3.title: Simplifying Multi-Variable Expressions
learningFocus: Combine like terms with multiple variables
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - algebraic simplification only
ALWAYS include commutative pairs to test understanding: xy and yx
Include non-like terms that look similar: x²y vs xy²
Test student recognition: 3xy + 5yx = 8xy (combine)
But x²y and xy² cannot be combined (unlike terms)
Use 2-3 variables maximum to avoid confusion
Ensure some terms can combine, some cannot
Final answer should group like terms properly

expansion-factorisation-node-4.title: Single Bracket Expansion with Distributive Law
learningFocus: Apply distributive law: a(b+c) = ab + ac
Multiply each term inside bracket by outside term
Handle negative multipliers with sign changes
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE mathTool when it helps visualization WITHOUT revealing answer
For simple expansion like 3(x+2), mathTool shows process not answer
CRITICAL: multiplier must match question (if question has -2, use -2)
CRITICAL: terms array must list individual terms from bracket
Example: For -2(4p-3q), use multiplier: -2, terms: ['4p', '-3q']
Sign handling rules: negative × positive = negative, negative × negative = positive
Test -(x+y) = -x-y and -(x-y) = -x+y patterns
Ensure all terms in bracket are multiplied (common error: 3(x+5) ≠ 3x+5)

expansion-factorisation-node-5.title: Expanding and Simplifying Multiple Single Brackets
learningFocus: Combine like terms with correct signs
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - process is sequential expansion then simplification
Process: Expand all brackets → Identify like terms → Combine
Test sign handling: 3(x+2) - 2(x-1) = 3x+6-2x+2 = x+8
Include multi-variable to test grouping: p(3p+q) = 3p²+pq
Ensure final answer combines all like terms
Test negative multipliers with subtraction between brackets
Final form should be fully simplified

expansion-factorisation-node-6.title: Double Bracket Expansion (FOIL Method)
learningFocus: Use FOIL: First, Outer, Inner, Last
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE multiplicationGrid to visualize four-term expansion
CRITICAL: expression1 and expression2 must match question exactly
Example: For (x+3)(x+5), use expression1: 'x+3', expression2: 'x+5'
Grid shows four products: top-left (x²), middle terms (x), bottom-right (constant)
Emphasize combining middle terms: (x+3)(x+5) → x²+5x+3x+15 → x²+8x+15
Common error to warn against: (x+2)(x+3) ≠ x²+6 (missing middle term)
Grid helps students see where each term comes from
All positive terms first, then introduce negatives in next section

expansion-factorisation-node-7.title: Double Brackets with Negative Terms
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE multiplicationGrid to show sign changes visually
CRITICAL: Use exact expressions including negative signs
Example: For (x-3)(x+5), use expression1: 'x-3', expression2: 'x+5'
Common errors: (x-2)(x-3) ≠ x²-5x-6 (wrong sign on last term)
Correct: (x-2)(x-3) = x²-3x-2x+6 = x²-5x+6
Grid shows sign of each product clearly
Test all combinations: (+,+), (+,-), (-,+), (-,-)

expansion-factorisation-node-8.title: Expanding (px+q)(rx+s) to Quadratic Form
learningFocus: Identify x² coefficient from p × r
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE multiplicationGrid to show quadratic structure
Grid clearly shows: top-left (prx²), middle (psx+qrx), bottom-right (qs)
Emphasize pattern: x² coefficient = p×r = 2×3 = 6
Middle term coefficient = ps+qr = 2×2+1×3 = 7
Constant term = q×s = 1×2 = 2
This pattern is CRITICAL for factorisation (reverse process)
Test understanding with different p,r combinations

expansion-factorisation-node-9.title: Recognizing Rectangular Array Patterns
learningFocus: Connect grid visual to algebraic expansion

exemplarProblems.problemText: Using a multiplication grid, expand (x+5)(x+3) and identify all four regions.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE multiplicationGrid with stepByStep=true for sequential reveal
Question explicitly mentions using grid method
Grid shows four distinct regions with color coding
Green: x² terms, Blue: x terms, Orange: constants
Students should identify: 'top-left gives x²', 'middle two give x terms'
This builds foundation for factorisation (working backwards)

expansion-factorisation-node-10.title: Expanding with Higher Powers
learningFocus: Apply exponent rule: x × x² = x³
Distinguish like from unlike terms with powers

exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: x²y + xy - xy² - xy = x²y - xy²

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - focus is on exponent arithmetic
Test exponent addition: xᵃ × xᵇ = xᵃ⁺ᵇ
Common error: x·x² ≠ x² (wrong), correct is x³
For multi-variable: ab(ac) = a¹⁺¹bc = a²bc
Ensure students recognize: x²y and xy² are UNLIKE terms (cannot combine)
But x²y + 3x²y = 4x²y (like terms, can combine)
Test both expansion AND subsequent simplification

expansion-factorisation-node-11.title: Complex Multi-Bracket Expansion
learningFocus: Use strategic order: expand pairs first
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - too complex, focus on strategy
First expand (x+1)(x+2) = x²+3x+2
Then multiply result by (x+3): (x²+3x+2)(x+3)
For multiple expressions: expand each separately, then add
Test student ability to organize complex work
Final answer should combine all like terms

expansion-factorisation-node-12.title: Factorising by Extracting Common Factors
learningFocus: Write in form a(b+c) from ab + ac
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool for factorisation - algebraic process
Process: Find HCF → Factor out → Write a(b+c)
Verification: Expand a(b+c) should equal original
Test 'completely factorised': largest possible factor
Example: 6x+9 = 3(2x+3) is complete, but 6x+9 = 2(3x+4.5) is wrong
For 12ab+18a: HCF is 6a (both numerical 6 and variable a)
Emphasize: factorisation is REVERSE of expansion
Common error: 6x+9 = 6(x+9) is wrong (should be 3(2x+3))

expansion-factorisation-node-13.title: Factorising with Negative Common Factors
learningFocus: Extract -1 as common factor when appropriate

negativePatterns: Second negative: ax - b with negative HCF

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - sign manipulation focus
Sign change rules: -x-y = -(x+y), -x+y = -(x-y)
For -6x-9: extract -3 to get -3(2x+3)
Alternative form acceptable: -3(2x+3) = 3(-2x-3)
Test: -15x+6 can be -3(5x-2) OR 3(-5x+2) - both valid
Verification critical: expand to check signs
Common error: forgetting sign change inside bracket

expansion-factorisation-node-14.title: Factorising with Squares and Cubes
learningFocus: Extract highest power common to all terms
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - algebraic factorisation
Highest power rule: from x³ and x², extract x²
Example: 6x³+9x² → 3x²(2x+3), NOT 3x(2x²+3x)
For multi-variable: 8a³b-12a²b²
Numerical HCF: 4
Variable HCF: a² (lowest power), b (lowest power)
Combined: 4a²b(2a-3b)
Test complete factorisation: no further factoring possible
Verification: expand to check

expansion-factorisation-node-15.title: Understanding Quadratic Factorisation Process
learningFocus: Understand factorisation as reverse of expansion
Find factor pairs of constant c
Identify pair where sum equals coefficient b

exemplarProblems.problemText: Explain how to factorise x² + 7x + 12 using factor pairs. What factors of 12 add to 7?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Factors of 12: (1,12), (2,6), (3,4). The pair (3,4) adds to 7. So x² + 7x + 12 = (x+3)(x+4)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE factoringVisualizer to show factor pair process
CRITICAL: Set a=1 for simple factorisation section
CRITICAL: b and c must match question values
Visualizer shows: factor pairs of c, which pair sums to b
This is conceptual understanding section - explain the method
Target form: x² + bx + c = (x+p)(x+q) where pq=c, p+q=b
Use multiplication grid in reverse
Question asks for explanation, not just answer

expansion-factorisation-node-16.title: Factorising Simple Quadratics
learningFocus: List factor pairs of c systematically
Test sums to find pair equal to b
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE factoringVisualizer with showSteps=false (just shows answer)
All c values ≤ 20 (simple section)
All b and c positive (save negative for later)
Process: List factors of c → Find pair summing to b → Write (x+p)(x+q)
Verification: Expand (x+2)(x+3) = x²+5x+6 ✓
Test systematic approach, not guessing

expansion-factorisation-node-17.title: Systematic Factorisation with Reasoning

exemplarProblems.problemText: Factorise x² + 11x + 18 and explain why you chose those factors.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE factoringVisualizer with highlighting
Question explicitly asks for reasoning/explanation
Test student understanding beyond rote factoring
Example reasoning: 'I eliminated (1,18) because 1+18=19, too large'
Strategic thinking: if b is small, factors should be close together
If b is large, factors should be far apart
Build efficiency through logical elimination

expansion-factorisation-node-18.title: Factorising with Large Constant Terms
learningFocus: List divisor pairs of large numbers systematically
Handle many factor pairs without overwhelm

systematicListing: Pairs: if d divides c, pair is (d, c/d)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE factoringVisualizer to show systematic search
Constants > 50 to test organization
Emphasize systematic listing: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6...
Test middle values often closest to b
Prime factorisation tip: 60 = 2²×3×5 helps find all divisors
Build stamina for complex factorisation

expansion-factorisation-node-19.title: Factorising with Both Factors Negative
learningFocus: Recognize b<0, c>0 means both factors negative
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE factoringVisualizer to show sign pattern
Pattern recognition: b<0 AND c>0 → both factors negative
Example: x²-7x+10 → need (-p)(-q)=10 and -p-q=-7
Verification: (x-2)(x-5) = x²-5x-2x+10 = x²-7x+10 ✓
Common error: (x+2)(x+5) gives x²+7x+10 (wrong signs)

expansion-factorisation-node-20.title: Factorising with One Negative Factor
learningFocus: Determine larger factor gets sign of b
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE factoringVisualizer to show sign determination
Pattern: c<0 means one +, one -
Rule: Larger factor gets sign of b
Need difference = 5 → try (6,-1): 6-1=5 ✓
Since b=+5 (positive), larger factor (6) is positive: (x+6)(x-1)
Verification critical for sign placement

expansion-factorisation-node-21.title: Sign Combination Strategy
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - focus on strategic thinking
Question asks to determine signs FIRST, then factorise
Test quick scenario recognition from b and c signs
Four scenarios to master:
1. c>0, b>0: both factors positive (x+p)(x+q)
2. c>0, b<0: both factors negative (x-p)(x-q)
3. c<0, b>0: larger positive (x+p)(x-q) where p>q
4. c<0, b<0: larger negative (x-p)(x+q) where p>q
Build fluency through mixed practice

expansion-factorisation-node-22.title: Understanding Factorisation with a≠1
learningFocus: Recognize when a≠1 requires different approach
See why common factor method doesn't work

exemplarProblems.problemText: Explain why 2x² + 7x - 15 cannot be factorised by just extracting common factors.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: There is no common factor among 2x², 7x, and -15 other than 1. We need (px+q)(rx+s) form where pr=2

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE multiplicationGrid in factorise mode
This is conceptual - explain WHY different method needed
Grid shows diagonal product pattern
Target form: (px+q)(rx+s) where pr=a, qs=c, ps+qr=b
Example: 2x²+7x-15 needs p·r=2, so try (2x+?)(x+?)
Question asks for understanding, not just answer

expansion-factorisation-node-23.title: Guess-and-Check Method for a≠1
learningFocus: List factor pairs of a and c
Check if x-coefficient sum equals b
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE multiplicationGrid to test combinations
Keep a=2 or 3 (not too complex)
Process: List factors of a: (1,2) or (1,3)
List factors of c, test in grid
For 2x²+7x+3: try (2x+1)(x+3)
Check middle: 2x·3 + 1·x = 6x+x = 7x ✓
If wrong, try different arrangement
Grid shows which combination works

expansion-factorisation-node-24.title: Reasoning Method (AC Method)
learningFocus: Find factors of (a×c) summing to b
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE factoringVisualizer with split-middle method
CRITICAL: a, b, c must match question exactly
AC Method steps:
1. Calculate AC = a×c = 2×(-15) = -30
2. Find factors of -30 that sum to b=7: -3 and 10
3. Split middle: 2x²-3x+10x-15
Visualizer shows each step clearly
More efficient than guess-and-check for large a

expansion-factorisation-node-25.title: Negative Leading Coefficient
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - focus on sign extraction
Process: Extract negative → Factorise positive form → Reapply negative
Alternative: distribute negative into one factor: (3-2x)(x+5)
Both forms valid, show both
Verification: expand both to check

expansion-factorisation-node-26.title: Grouping Using Multiplication Frame
learningFocus: Identify common factor in each row/column
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE multiplicationGrid in factorise mode
Frame method: arrange terms in 2×2 grid
Read factors from row/column headers
Example: xy + 3x + 2y + 6
Grid: [x, 3; 2, 6] → factors (x+2)(y+3)
Verify by expanding: (x+2)(y+3) = xy+3x+2y+6 ✓
Grid makes factors obvious

expansion-factorisation-node-27.title: Grouping by Pairs Method
learningFocus: Group four terms into two pairs
Extract common factor from each pair
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - pairing method focus
Method: Group pairs → Extract from each → Final extraction
Example: 3x+3y+ax+ay = (3x+3y)+(ax+ay) = 3(x+y)+a(x+y) = (3+a)(x+y)
Key: both pairs must have same binomial factor
If not, try different pairing arrangement
Verification: expand to check

expansion-factorisation-node-28.title: Choosing Correct Term Arrangement

exemplarProblems.problemText: Find correct arrangement then factorise: pr + qr + ps + qs

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - strategic thinking focus
Challenge: terms given in non-obvious order
Student must rearrange before grouping
Test different pairings until common binomial emerges
Some expressions have multiple valid arrangements
Build problem-solving flexibility

expansion-factorisation-node-29.title: Combined Extraction and Grouping
learningFocus: Extract common factor first when present
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - multi-step process
Strategy: Check for HCF first → Extract if present → Group remaining
Example: 6xy+9x+10y+15
No overall HCF
Verify: no further factorisation possible
Test combining multiple techniques

expansion-factorisation-node-30.title: Perfect Square Sum Pattern

exemplarProblems.problemText: Expand (2a + 5)² and verify using area model.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE multiplicationGrid to show (a+b)(a+b) structure
CRITICAL: expression1 and expression2 must be IDENTICAL
Example: For (x+3)², use expression1: 'x+3', expression2: 'x+3'
Grid shows: a², ab, ab, b² → a² + 2ab + b²
Emphasize: middle term is 2ab (TWO rectangles of area ab)
Common error: (x+3)² ≠ x²+9 (missing 6x)
Correct: (x+3)² = x²+6x+9
Build foundation for factorising perfect squares

expansion-factorisation-node-31.title: Perfect Square Difference Pattern

exemplarProblems.problemText: Compare (x+3)² and (x-3)². What is similar and what is different?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Both give x² + constant. (x+3)² = x²+6x+9, (x-3)² = x²-6x+9. Middle term sign differs but constant is positive in both

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE multiplicationGrid with identical expressions
CRITICAL: For (x-5)², use expression1: 'x-5', expression2: 'x-5'
Emphasize: (-b)² = b² so last term is POSITIVE
Common error: (x-5)² ≠ x²-25 (missing middle, wrong sign)
Correct: (x-5)² = x²-10x+25
Middle term is -2ab (negative from -b-b)
Last term is +b² (negative times negative = positive)
Compare with (a+b)² to show relationship

expansion-factorisation-node-32.title: Expanding Using Perfect Square Identities
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - using identity as shortcut
Identity: (a±b)² = a²±2ab+b²
Process: Square first, double product, square second
Common error: (2x)² = 2x² is WRONG, correct is 4x²
Test coefficient squaring: (ka)² = k²a²
Middle term: 2×first×second (must multiply coefficients)
For (2x-5y)²: middle is 2(2x)(-5y) = -20xy

expansion-factorisation-node-33.title: Factorising Perfect Square Trinomials
learningFocus: Take square roots of first and last terms

exemplarProblems.problemText: Check if 16y² + 20y + 25 is a perfect square, then factorise if possible.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Not a perfect square. √16y² = 4y, √25 = 5, but 2(4y)(5) = 40y ≠ 20y. Cannot factorise as perfect square

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE factoringVisualizer for verification
Three tests for perfect square:
1. Three terms
2. First and last are perfect squares
3. Middle = ±2×√first×√last
Example: x²+10x+25
Test 1: ✓ three terms
Test 3: 10x = 2(x)(5)? Yes ✓
Therefore: (x+5)²
Include NON-perfect squares to test discrimination
If not perfect square, state 'Not a perfect square'
Verification: expand (x+5)² = x²+10x+25 ✓

expansion-factorisation-node-34.title: Discovering Middle Term Cancellation

exemplarProblems.problemText: Expand (x + 3)(x - 3) showing all four terms, then simplify.
Explain why (a+b)(a-b) has no middle term in the final answer.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: When expanded, you get a² - ab + ab - b². The middle terms -ab and +ab are opposites and cancel to 0, leaving only a² - b²

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
INCLUDE multiplicationGrid to show cancellation visually
CRITICAL: expression1 and expression2 opposite signs only
Example: expression1: 'x+3', expression2: 'x-3'
Grid shows four terms: x², -3x, +3x, -9
Emphasize cancellation: -3x + 3x = 0
Result: only TWO terms (x² - 9)
This is discovery section - ask for explanation
Pattern: (a+b)(a-b) = a²-b² always (no middle term)

expansion-factorisation-node-35.title: Expanding Using Difference of Squares
learningFocus: Apply identity: square first - square second
generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - using identity as shortcut
Identity: (a+b)(a-b) = a² - b²
Shortcut: Just square first, subtract square of second
Example: (x+5)(x-5) → x² - 5² = x² - 25
Order doesn't matter: (a-b)(a+b) = (a+b)(a-b) = a²-b²
Result always has exactly TWO terms
Test coefficient squaring: (ka)² = k²a²

expansion-factorisation-node-36.title: Factorising Difference of Squares
learningFocus: Apply to mental math and problem solving

exemplarProblems.problemText: Explain why x² + 25 cannot be factorised using difference of squares.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Difference of squares requires SUBTRACTION (a²-b²). x²+25 is a sum (+), not a difference (-), so the identity doesn't apply

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem. Maximum TWO if mental math
INCLUDE factoringVisualizer with method='difference-squares'
CRITICAL: Set b=0 for difference of squares (no middle term)
CRITICAL: c must be negative for difference
Pattern recognition: Two terms, both squares, subtraction
Process: Take √first and √second, write (√first + √second)(√first - √second)
Consecutive squares: n²-(n-1)² = (n+n-1)(n-n+1) = (2n-1)(1) = 2n-1
CRITICAL: Distinguish from sum of squares (a²+b² CANNOT be factorised)
Include both factorisation and application problems
Verification: expand (a+b)(a-b) to check
